newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft's third-quarter profit up 85 percent.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft's third-quarter profit up 85 percent.

text.p: Microsoft Corp.'s fiscal third-quarter profit jumped 85 percent to $1.04 billion, the world's largest software maker reported Thursday, crediting sales of its latest Microsoft Office package.

Net income, equivalent to 79 cents a share, rose from earnings of $562 million a year ago, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31. The latest results easily topped Wall Street's consensus analyst forecast of 64 cents a share, according to First Call.
Revenues totalled $3.21 billion, a 45 percent increase over the $2.21 billion racked up in the same quarter a year ago. Analysts on average had predicted revenues of about $2.9 billion.

Microsoft released its fiscal 1997 third-quarter results after financial markets closed. In after-hours trading, the Redmond, Wash.-based company's stock jumped $4.625 to $102.75 from its Nasdaq closing price, dealers said.
"Worldwide acceptance of Microsoft Office 97 ignited these outstanding results," Microsoft Chief Financial Officer Mike Brown said in a statement.

Office 97, the latest upgrade of the company's best-selling software package, was launched in January. It combines "productivity applications" such as word processing and spreadsheets that accounted for an estimated $2 billion of the company's $8.7 billion in the prior fiscal year.
Brown said Microsoft also realised "solid gains" from sales of operating systems.
Microsoft makes the bulk of its money from "platforms," including the operating systems preloaded onto new personal computers, which generate about one-third of the company's revenues.
"However," Brown cautioned, "incredible results like these are seldom duplicated, and we are mindful of the very tough comparisons we will have in fiscal 1998."
